review.title: Student Dropout Risk Assessment in Undergraduate Course at Residential University
review.abstract: Student dropout prediction is an indispensable for numerous intelligent systems to measure the education system and success rate of any university as well as throughout the university in the world. Therefore, it becomes essential to develop efficient methods for prediction of the students at risk of dropping out, enabling the adoption of proactive process to minimize the situation. Thus, this research work propose a prototype machine learning tool which can automatically recognize whether the student will continue their study or drop their study using classification technique based on decision tree and extract hidden information from large data about what factors are responsible for dropout student. Further the contribution of factors responsible for dropout risk was studied using discriminant analysis and to extract interesting correlations, frequent patterns, associations or casual structures among significant datasets, Association rule mining was applied. In this study, the descriptive statistics analysis was carried out to measure the quality of data using SPSS 20.0 statistical software and application of decision tree and association rule were carried out by using WEKA data mining tool.

metadata.title: Student’s Dropout Risk Assessment in Undergraduate Course at Residential University

sections.text: 2 | P a g eStudent drop-out prediction is indispensable to many intelligent systems for measuring the education system and success rate at any university and anywhere in the world. Therefore, it is essential to develop efficient methods for predicting students at risk of dropping out of studies, which make it possible to minimize the situation through proactive procedures. Thus, this research proposes a prototype machine learning tool that can automatically detect whether the student will continue his studies or stop his studies using decision tree-based classification techniques. In this study, descriptive statistical analysis was performed to measure the quality of the data using discriminatory analysis and to extract interesting correlations, frequent patterns, associations or casual structures between significant data sets while applying Association rule mining. In this study, descriptive statistical analysis was performed to measure the quality of the data using SPSS 20.0 statistical software and the application of decision tree and association rules.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: We live in an age when the accumulation of data is simple and inexpensive. Today, the amount of information stored is increasing day by day in all areas. Unfortunately, the amount of machine-readable information can be increased, the ability to understand and use it does not keep pace with its growth. However, the data can be used to generate useful information for decision-making, and the data can be applied in various real-world applications such as market analysis, education and scientific exploration. [18] If the data is rich in quality and quantity, reliable information can be generated in the data stored over the years.

sections.heading: 1.1 Data Mining
sections.text: "Data mining," often known as knowledge discovery in databases (KDD), refers to the mining of knowledge from vast amounts of data. [18] Data mining techniques are used to uncover patterns and relationships hidden in vast amounts of data that are helpful for decision-making. While data mining and KDD are often treated as synonyms, in fact data mining is part of the knowledge-gathering process. Data mining is defined as "the non-trivial process of identifying valid, new, previously unknown, potentially useful information, and ultimately understandable patterns from data in databases." [53] Finding useful patterns in data is known under different names in different communities (e.g. knowledge extraction, information discovery, data bagging, data archeology, information harvesting, data / pattern analysis, and business intelligence). [53]

sections.heading: 1.1.1 Data Mining Task
sections.text: Description: Describe the data set briefly and summarily and present interesting data in a humanly interpretable or comprehensible format. For example, clustering and association rule, etc. Prediction: construct one or more models, draw conclusions from the data set and try to predict unknown or future values of other interesting variables, e.g. classification and regression analysis, etc.

sections.heading: 1.1.2 Data Mining Functionalities
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive on their own if they do not put themselves in a position to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 1.2 Educational Data Mining
sections.text: Educational data mining is the application of data mining. It is an emerging interdisciplinary field of research that deals with the development of methods for researching data that originate from an educational context. Educational data mining is an emerging trend that is designed to automatically explore the unique types of data from large repositories of educational data. Very often, this data is comprehensive, fine-grained and precise. The Educational Data Mining Community defines EDM as follows: Educational data mining is an emerging discipline that deals with the development of methods for researching the unique types of data that originate from educational institutions, and uses these methods to better understand the students and the settings in which they learn. Data mining is the area of discovering new and potentially useful information from the extraction of huge amounts of data. We know that large amounts of data are collected from associations, the relationships required to find the data base, and the different types of data that are used.

sections.heading: 1.3 Need of Current Research
sections.text: Predicting early dropouts is a challenging task in higher education. Data analysis is one way to reduce the dropout rate and increase the enrollment rate at the university. In fact, the number of first-year dropouts is quite high, especially in the first semester.The dropout rate at the boarding school depends on the education system introduced by the university. Current research results are as follows: 12 | P a g e Predicting dropouts at an early stage of studies not only helps management to focus more on the smart students, but also to make more efforts in developing programs for the weaker ones in order to improve their progress and at the same time to try to avoid dropouts. The knowledge generated will be very useful to better understand the problem and to have adequate planning or decision to reduce the dropout rate. This study is quite useful for better planning and implementing educational programs and infrastructure to increase the enrollment rate of certain students at the university.

sections.heading: 1.4 Social Implication of this Research
sections.text: Dropouts are also more likely than graduates to become dependent on benefits, engage in illegal activities, and experience health and affective problems [54, 55, 13]. Finally, a high dropout rate creates a negative impulse for young people in a society, especially in difficult economic times when a high school degree does not guarantee a job. Such dynamics could encourage even higher dropout rates in the future. To overcome these problems, this research will be very helpful. To reduce dropout rates or predict students who need special attention, we need to focus on parental support, personal and family factors, the campus environment, and the quality of education. The results of this case study focus on policy makers with an overview of the dropout problem research and the best strategies to build an early warning system that can control the most pressing issues facing institutions.

sections.heading: METHODOLOGY
sections.text: In the present study, information on various parameters was collected using a structured questionnaire based on a face-to-face interview from a composite sample of 220 undergraduate (BCA and B.Tech) students in Computer Science / Information Technology at the University. Predicting the dropout status of students, whether they continue their studies or not, requires many parameters such as personal, academic, social, environmental, etc. Variables are required for effective forecasting. As the present study stands in relation to the classification of the various quantitative and qualitative factors that contribute to the process of knowledge gathering and data dropout, this information will be useful for management to reduce the dropout rate on campus. In order to achieve the above objectives, the following steps have been followed (Figure 1): Figure 1: Working Methodology Problem StatementData GatheringData MiningPingPingPre-ProcessingClassificationEvaluationEvaluation21

sections.text: The results of the study show that most of them are not self-denial, but self-denial.

sections.heading: 3.2 Data Selection and Transformation
sections.text: Prior to applying the prescribed model, data pre-processing was used to measure the quality and suitability of the data. In this step, only the attributes required for data mining were selected, missing values were removed, noisy data smoothed out, relevant attributes were selected from the database or removed irrelevant attributes, outlier values were identified or removed from the data set and inconsistencies in the data were removed. Some of the irrelevant parameters were removed from the database, such as ID, age, date of birth, category, marital status, place of residence, mother tongue, religion, the gender field containing only one value - female, because the university only concerns female students, the marital field containing a value - unmarried, etc. A categorical variable is constructed on the basis of the numerical parameter percentage in secondary and secondary education. "A grade scale will be used for evaluating the students" performance in school, with a grade A - 85% - 85% - 85% of students "annual incomes.

sections.heading: 3.3 Data Analysis Techniques
sections.text: In this study, a quantitative and a qualitative data analysis using statistical methods and data mining methods must be carried out.

sections.heading: Statistical Methods
sections.text: The data collected was analyzed using SPSS statistical software to measure the quality of the data based on descriptive statistics, crosstabs and statistical tests. Examine each variable using cross buttons. The entire student was examined to understand the reasons for the withdrawal.

sections.heading: Data Mining Methods
sections.text: After proper collection, verification and transformation of the data using appropriate measures, data mining classification and decision tree approaches were applied to predict dropout rates and causes at an early stage of their studies, either before or after completion of their first year of study. The classification model is implemented using the WEKA tool. WEKA has several classifiers available, but ID3 was used for the purpose of the study. Important attributes analyses were performed to classify attributes by meaning based on information gained. Correlation-based feature selection (CFS) using best-first search technology and discrimination analysis were used to classify and select the most useful attributes. Further association rules mining techniques were used to discover relationships between seemingly unrelated variables in large databases with great potential for various real-life applications, including business and industry. 24 | P a g e

sections.heading: Correlation-Based Feature Selection
sections.text: The feature selection is used to select a subset of input data that is most useful for analysis and future prediction by eliminating features that are not irrelevant to any predictive information. Feature selection is used to increase predictive accuracy and reduce the complexity of learning outcomes. [28] In this study, correlation-based feature selection (CFS) was used to find the feature parts that are strongly correlated with the class, but minimal correlation between features in combination with the Best-First-Search (BFS) search strategy. The best first search method starts with empty feature parts and generates all possible individual feature extensions. The subset with the highest score is selected and expanded in the same way by adding individual features. If the extension of a subset does not result in improvement, the search is continued back to the next-best unexpanded subset and continued from there. "The subset with the highest score is selected and expanded in the same way by adding individual features.

sections.heading: ID3 (Iterative Dichotomizer 3)
sections.text: The ID3 algorithm (Iterative Dichotomizer 3) was invented by J. Ross Quinlan in 1979 and is used to build the decision tree using the information theory invented in 1948. It builds the decision tree from top to bottom, without traceability. Information Gain is used to select the best attribute for classification.

sections.heading: Entropy
sections.text: If entropy is 1, it means that the dataset is homogeneous. Entropy is calculated by formula: () = − Where, Pi is the probability that S belongs to the class i. Information gain It measures the expected decrease in entropy. ID3 calculates the gain of all attributes and selects the attribute with the highest gain. sections.heading: CFS
sections.text: Create a decision tree (ID3 algorithm) Evaluate the accuracy of model26 | P a g e (,) = () − | | | | () () where values (A) are the set of all possible values for attribute A and Sv is the subset of S for which attribute A has a value v. The attribute with the highest information gain among the attributes is located as a root node in the decision tree.

sections.heading: Implementation of ID3 Algorithm
sections.text: Step 1: Calculating the classification entropy. Step 2: Calculating the information gain for each attribute using the classification attribute. Step 3: Selecting the attribute with the highest information gain. Step 4: Removing the node attribute for future calculation. Step 5: Repeat Steps 2-4 until all attributes have been used. Experiments are performed using the Weka tool.

sections.heading: Performance Evaluation
sections.text: To evaluate the performance of the classification, precision, recall, and F measurement were used as performance benchmarks. = = = + = + = + − = 2 х к +

sections.heading: Association Rule
sections.text: To measure the usefulness of association rules, statistical significance is defined as support and goodness as a trust framework. Support S is used to define the percentage of transactions in the data set containing the item set. (→) = Trust is defined as conditional probability. Trust (X = > Y) is the ratio of the number of transactions containing XUY. (→) = () () The trust of a rule measures the strength of the rule as a correlation between the previous and the sequence, while support measures the frequency of the preceding and subsequent correlation. The Apriori algorithm, used for association rule mining, was developed in 1994 by R. Agrawal and R. Srikant [2] for the removal of common items for Boolean association rules.

sections.heading: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: The methodology described in the previous chapter forms the basis for data collection, but this chapter focuses on analyzing and interpreting data using statistical tools and data mining techniques; the data collected was compiled in Microsoft Excel 2007 software; the SPSS software was used to distribute frequency and analyze descriptive statistics for each response variable; and, after measuring data quality, data mining classification techniques were used to investigate the factors that affect dropout from university; and then the causes of dropout were analyzed.

sections.heading: 4.1 Description of the sample
sections.text: According to the first chapter, the purpose of the study was to analyze the factors influencing drop-outs and their reasons. In this study, data were collected on the basis of questionnaires sent to respondents by hand (N = 300) from the BCA and B.Tech (CS / IT) courses, together with letters of approval from the university authority and instructions for research problems. After the collection of the data sets, approximately 80 data sets were deleted due to incomplete information; the remaining data sets (N = 220) were analyzed, which contain information such as socio-demographic factors (age, category, marital status, marital status, religion), parental status (annual income, parental education, parental occupation), respondent educational profile (grade in secondary school, grade in secondary school, location, educational medium, stream grammar school, admission criteria, source of educational expenditure, study duration) and respondents "attitudes to university (course satisfaction, curriculum, education system, infrastructure, extracurricular activities, study outcomes, etc.).

sections.heading: One Way Classification
sections.text: The one-way frequency distribution is the simplest form of analysis, and one that often provides much of the basic information required is the tabulation of results, question by question, as "one-way tables." Of course, this does not determine which respondents produced particular combinations of answers, but it is often a first step in obtaining summaries of individual variables, which is most useful for determining the typical values of the variables, verifying the adoption of statistical procedures, and verifying the quality of data. In this section, the frequency distribution of 220 sample cases collected at the university level was elaborated to examine the nature and quality of data for each variable related to demographic, educational, and institutional factors of the respondents. Figure 3 shows the level of study of the respondents: More than half of the respondents (58%) were enrolled in the Bachelor of Computer Application and 42% of the respondents were enrolled in the Bachelor of Technology.

sections.heading: Demographic Profile of Respondents
sections.text: The demographic problems examined in this study were age, category, residential status and marital status. Table 2 shows the demographic profile of the participants. The age range of the participants ranged from 16 to 23 years. More than half of the respondents (131) belong to the age group 18-20 years; while about 70 of the respondents are younger than 18 years and the remaining 19 respondents are 20 years and older. Regarding to the category, the majority of the respondents (78.2%) came from the general and a few of them from the categories OBC (20.5%) and SC (1.4%). The rural-urban distribution clearly indicates that the majority of the registered respondents (76.8%) came from the urban area, while only 30 | P a g e23.2% of the respondents came from rural areas. The low participation from rural areas could be due to lack of awareness about university, financial constraints and the low level of parental attitude towards education of girls in higher technical education.

sections.heading: Socio-economic Profile of Respondent’s Parents
sections.text: It was found that both the father and the mother of the respondents were very well educated. It was found that 85.9% of the fathers had a university degree or more, whereas about 71.8% of the mothers had a university degree or more, the remaining 14.1% of the fathers and 28.1% of the mothers were able to get involved in the economy (14.1%) and agriculture (4.1%).

To achieve the goal, the following steps were performed in sequential order:

sections.text: The reason given by the students for dropping out of ICT courses at the university level was divided into four factors: family problems, health problems, personal problems and institutional problems listed in Table 23. sections.heading: CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Conclusion
sections.text: The reason for this is the fact that in recent years, the number of university entrants in Germany has increased by more than a third, while the number of university entrants in the USA has increased many times over.

sections.heading: 5.2 Suggestion
sections.text: Although the dropout rate among students is very low (< 20%), which is a good indicator for the university, although the university should place due emphasis on minimizing the dropout rate, the well-planned and needs-oriented advice and guidance on how to deal with academic life at the university, basic life skills, and potential problems that female students may face should be given to female students immediately after admission. Therefore, university authorities must organize workshops, seminars, and conferences on equality, affirmative action, and multiculturalism in order to strengthen the positive beliefs that already exist regarding affirmative action. Such an approach will certainly reduce the dropout rate among students. Bonding and university success are influenced by many factors in which the institutional environment occupies the lions. Institutional factors include interaction with academic and administrative staff, gender-specific institutional roles, traditional academic expectations of girls, and so on. These gender issues need to be addressed through generational policies such as international governance.
